comments.commentBody: Great post Andy.
Maybe I'm not au courant with the NFL rules. Are the other 10 guys on the field when the punter makes a mistake not allowed to tackle the ball carrier if he's famous?

Here's a thought: Most draft picks don't pan out yet GM's put a premium on them. Why doesn't a creative GM try something different by trading veteran stars to acquire draft picks in rounds 1-3 and then trading those draft picks for young players or diamonds in the rough?

For example, the Giants could trade DE Osi for a #1 and a #3 or #4. They could trade RB Bradshaw for a #2 or #3. Maybe they could then trade a #1 and two #3's to SF for Patrick Willis and a #5. The net-net: 29 year-old Osi,a #2 and a #3 for 25 year-old Willis. This isn't a perfect example but I think there's a way to use over-valued draft picks and "aging" star players to acquire players on the verge of stardom.

Thoughts?

Dennis's comment (post #42) is totally incorrect. Kodachrome film can NOT be processed by Fuji labs - Kodachrome film is NOT processed in the same chemistry as Fujichrome and Ektachrome - both are E-6 color reversal slide films processed in E-6 chemistry and both Fujichrome and Ektachrome can be processed at home if you have the right equipment, temperature controllled chemistry and skills learned from trial-and-error. Kodachrome could never be processed at home by anyone.

Scott Kilborn
ACE Camera Index www.acecam.com

Happy New Year to all!
Good, hard (for me) puzzle.....but I really stopped by to tip my hat to our Patrick. Thank you so much, Patrick for your wonderful blogs this past year. It has been a real treat getting to know you and your delightful sense of whimsy. I'll miss seeing you in the Blogger's Chair! Wishing you all the best! Give Ashen and Noir a hug from Patricia and one for yourself too, and tell them (and you!) to check in now and then. We'll miss you! Happy New Year!

@MOL.....congratulations on winning Matt Gaffney's puzzle challenge for this past week :-)
Glad Matt's site was brought to our attention through Wordplay, it is a fun contest!

It looked for a while like a Krozel Home Run was within sight, but I was defeated in the end by the NW quadrant.. Never heard of JJ Abrams or Mulan or (shame on me!) Laila Ali. TIME AFTER TIME for 15 down ought to  have  been a gimme, but I was hung up on STICk IN ONE'S CRAW for 35 across; eventually, I got unstuck. Similarly, for 43 down I had TAGORE instead of SARTRE (who ever knew he was into ego transcendence?) until I saw the light.
Just curious: what are your numbers telling us about some of the rookies not on the list? Mostly, I mean Webb and Tebow.

Just came back from the holiday activities to check on this blog.

I am looking through the new posts since my last one, and will post my thoughts on D-Ferg's simulation and response soon. There are some revisions for something I overlooked in my post Hans #12.

But something quick first:

Tom E. #22:

The conditional probability I wrote down in Hans #12 is conditional on the state of the day and it does depend on the the proportional population from day to day but it holds daily not just one particular day. The fact it is a daily transitional probability itself does not prevent it from being useful for drawing short term or long term conclusions under certain circumstances. I will discuss it further in my later post. For example, it is the sole method in determining which specie to switch to overnight ---- in fact, I will post a revision on Hans #12 on Q3.
Pascal had it irght: Men never do evil so cheerfully and completely as when they do it from religious motivation, ( or superstition).

The government forces in Uganda could eliminate the LRA in about 7 days. Yet, they don't. And Western nations provide millions in aid to Uganda. No different than the days of Idi Amin. Just threaten to tale away the foreign aid, Kony will be in The Hague faster than you can swing a machete.
The LRA atrocity seems to follow a time-honored recipe for human rights abuses: the obsessive desire to reach a religious or political ideal coupled with a healthy dose of madness.

Nelson Alexander,

It doesn't take much of a brain to figure out how patently ridiculous your comparisons are, but I suppose it might have been predicted that one of your ilk would stumble across this board to try and make them. If you believe that all religions are the same, I've got bad news: your atheism is just religion by another name, and you are captive to its orthodoxy.

I am sorry to contribute to the distraction from what is a brilliant and disturbing post, but I can only take so much foolishness.

Think of a box of crayons. Anyone seized by the fervor for creating a dogma set around the particular light burning in their brain, one by one they take a crayon out of the box and in broad strokes set out their Rules for their Religion.
Where do you think he got the idea to use the cross?

As an anthropologist, it disturbs me that the most insightful claim in this story is that Kony is "bizarre." Why were no area studies specialists interviewed? The Lord's Resistance Army's creation and harnessing of religious ritual is no more or less bizarre than any other set of human beliefs or practices. And in saying this I am no more supporting Kony than O'Donnell (I'm not a witch, I'm you). American religious apocalypticism (cf.Sharlet's study _The Family_) and the desire to see societal or divine wrath visited upon the living (Fox News), the invocation of divine power to protect society or exorcise the "demonic" (Palin) should all be familiar to readers of the Times. Mormons often believe that their garments protect believers from violent deaths; Catholics often believe this about their medals, and Evangelicals about biblical verses written on paper. And about the apparently arbitrary prohibitions? Mary Douglas noted long ago that the arbitrary prohibitions of Leviticus are set up to create holiness in subjects. Even the sexual prohibitions should not be surprising to anyone familiar with ideas of sexual abstinence and prowess in sports.

The question for me is, how does this article help us understand the conflict or the larger context? While the information is interesting, it is neither as bizarre or "premodern" as you might think (either in the international or African context) nor especially elucidating. This article is just another example of exoticising others but without much substance. Get over the surprise and tell us something interesting.

Admit it. In general, Africa is a sink-hole, mired in its primitiveness…and a sink-hole for American tax-payer dollars. They are, in general, a blight upon themselves, and to a growing degree, upon the world. They have manifested time and time again an ineptitude to rise out of the overpopulated mire that they have created for themselves. Again, in general, they are ultra sexist, ultra-intolerant, ultra-racist, and ultra-uneducated… i.e… primitive. Time to cut the cord … and tend to our own backyard.

Given the state of critical mass that the American economy is rapidly reaching, not one more American tax-payer dollar should be expended there. Those dollars should be used to address our unemployment, job creation, our lack of health-care for millions, our elders who are eating cat-food, our elders who must choose between food and medications, our growing number of homeless, our young families that can no longer even aspire to be middle-class, our disgraceful failed public educational system, our neglected veterans, our degenerating infrastructure, and a plethora of other palatable maladies staring us directly in the face… right now.

Leave Africa to its own devices. Private charitable organizations that desire to raise money to expend in Africa is fine… it’s their prerogative and their business. Individuals that desire to volunteer for humanitarian endeavors there… fine… it’s their prerogative and their business. Entrepreneurs that wish to sojourn there to create a business model… go for it… though I’d prefer to see that option being undertaken here in the US. American corporations outsourcing jobs to Africa (and elsewhere) that should stay in the US, to take advantage of pseudo-slave labor… no.

If the world is a global village… Africa is its ghetto.

The british came and left, the russians came and left the american came 9 years
ago and are ready to leave. what you leave behind is an angry nation of people bent on getting a revenge.the kid that was 9 years ago that lost his mom or dad or sister
is now 18 and angry.What do you say.leave this country alone.

My husband and I were both born in 1950, which makes us "boomers"; but if we are glum, it is not because we feel unfulfilled. We are glum because articles such as this one describe us as "pigs in a python" and, in envisioning our "final stage," appear to be waiting for us to die.

In fact, if those born in the second half of the twentieth century -- and not just baby boomers, born in the 1950s -- are swigging their skim milk, eating their granola, and expecting to leader longer, productive lives, that is because advances in health care, better nutrition, life-long exercise and a generally healthier life style, have increased life expectancies for all. Moreover, despite the reality that many people live long, but are disabled, today's sixty year olds are not delusional to believe that they are healthier than their parents were at their age; they are healthier. Ask most eighty year-olds, and they will tell you that they did not run daily, eschew tobacco and fatty foods, meditate or engage in other relaxation techniques, or eat low-fat, low-animal protein diets. My mother could not run almost 4 miles daily at age 60. I and many others my age can, and do. Moreover, because we are healthier at 60 than were our parents, my husband and I hope that, barring a medical catastrophe (those genes; the environment), we will be healthy, not disabled, at eighty or eighty-five. So America had better stop waiting for us baby boomers to die, or trying to convince us that we are crazy to feel healthy. Most of us aren't going anywhere.

The real problem, and resentment, stems from the fact that, not only will we boomers be collecting Social Security and Medicare for a long, long time -- but we want to work. We refuse to step aside, because we are healthy, and need incomes. Trying to convince us that we are delusional or selfish because we won't conform to previous, outmoded standards and actuarial tables predicting at what age people will become too old, infirm, or senile to go to work each day, won't solve the problem.

There may be more boomers than there are members of other age cohorts, but all of those born after mid-twentieth century, and certainly the kids born today -- my 21 year old son, his future children -- are going to live a long time. Rather than characterizing the boomers as pigs, whether in the python or in the marketplace, it behooves whoever plans economies, or writes about social issues, to figure out how to get all these younger older people jobs.

As the Boomers enter the autumn of their lives, they will soon have to reckon with intergenerational strife caused by the Boomers' self-absorption.  Why should later generations accept the Boomers' legacy of fiscal irresponsibility, crumbling infrastructure, environmental damage, urban sprawl, breakdown of civil society, war, and underfunded pensions and social benefits.  The Boomers had a chance to build upon the Greatest Generation's achievements of balanced growth, and comfort balanced with responsbility.  Instead, they have squandered the opportunity, leaving a mess that younger generations will need to contend with.  The principal US political rift in the coming years won't be left/right, north/south or Republican/Democrat; it will be Boomers vs. later generations.  If the Boomers think those who follow them will pay for their entitlements and accept the Boomers' continued leadership, they have another thing coming.  Those born after the Boomers will have their hands full getting themselves out of the mire they've inherited from the Boomers.

Amusing, this popular sales pitch in media that the Boomers are overly fascinated with themselves. According to that same media, the current generation obsessively follows the beat of the new corporate America as defined by Apple, Facebook, Google and the lot. Tweeting their way to a social networking nirvana where every facet and whim of personal experience is shared by all. What could possibly be more self-centered and self-celebrating than that? In the not so old days, communion was accomplished by shared experience - not virtually, by upthrust digital devices, but by actually being there. Never again, it looks like. Happy to be born in '56.
Let's take a moment to "lighten up" on the Boomers. Each one is an individual and a survivor. The rest is just talk.

Interesting article. Many of us do not have the attributes that the cited authour attibutes to us - “It created a sense of entitlement that had not existed before,” Mr. Gillon said. “We became more concerned with our own emotional well-being, whereas to older generations that was considered soft and fluffy.” My parents were of the older generation and softness and fluff were not allowed. TV was strictly limited. And we were taught discipline. It's the children of today that cause worry. I see everywhere kids whose parents don't control them and cater to the kids like there is no limit.

Happy Birthday, Mr. Nachreiner! Long may you wave!

For an article that is supposed to be about a self-absorbed generation, he sounds about as UN-self-absorbed as anyone can be. The rest of the boomers, take heed.

"The self-aware, or self-absorbed, feel less self-fulfilled, and thus are racked with self-pity." This article would have been a lot more informative and indeed persuasive if there were not for this thread of labeling people(despite of the author's repeated point that you cannot characterize the boomer generation). Every generation---from the greatest generation to the millennial--can be neatly encapsulated in stereotypes, but doing makes understanding more difficult, not easier--in exactly the same way that prejudices of any kind mask reality rather than reveal it.
